items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely all day today, Wednesday 8 December and overnight tonight. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 9 December.
This flood alert is no longer in force due to levels falling below levels of concern. We will continue to monitor the situation and forecast and re-issue if necessary.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Following recent rainfall, river levels on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect low  lying areas near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.  With little rain forecast, levels are expected to peak later this afternoon before starting to recede. Avoid using low lying footpaths, particularly around the lake edge and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Leek river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure based upon the forecast which given the high winds remains changeable. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 18 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Marchington and Uttoxeter river gauges as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Picknall Brook, Marchington Brook and Rolleston Brook.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure based upon the forecast which remains changeable due to the high winds. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 18 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall from Storm Barra, river levels remain high on the Rivers Clyst and Culm and may respond to overnight rainfall. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible overnight into Thursday 09/12/2021. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Thursday morning, 09/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding at the present time, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with a moderate band of rain this evening, Wednesday 08/12/2021, however this is not expected to cause flooding impacts. The catchments remain wet and we continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.98m, Bredwardine 4.9m to 5.0m Thursday morning, Belmont 4.8m to 5.0m Thursday afternoon, Old Wye Bridge 4.3m to 4.5m Thursday afternoon, Mordiford 4.1m to 4.4m Thursday evening, Ross-on-wye 3.7m to 4 Friday morning. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until 10/12/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Leintwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 09/12/21 by 17:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.4m to 4.0m Friday morning. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: The level of the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake remains marginally above Flood Alert threshold and is falling slowly. Other rivers in the area have fallen to winter baseflow levels. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with a moderate band of rain this evening, Wednesday 08/12/2021. While this is not expected to cause widespread flooding impacts, the catchments are wet and it may be enough to keep Sherborne Lake just above Alert level with a low level of flood risk in the local area. We will continue to monitor the weather and the Lake level over the coming days, and we will keep reviewing the need for this Alert. There may continue to be a localised risk of flooding to low lying land and roads in the area. We do not anticipate flooding of properties, based on the current forecast. Please remain vigilant and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise and remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We have been clearing debris from weed screens and we will continue to monitor the forecast. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening and overnight.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   This flood alert remains active as further rainfall is forecast over the next 18 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are continuing to remain high, but are falling slowly, at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. River levels could respond quickly to even small amounts of new rainfall, as the catchments are now saturated, so this Flood Alert remains in force overnight (08/12/2021). We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This Flood Alert may be removed tomorrow morning (09/12/2021), if the river level has continued to fall overnight, but this will be based on an updated weather forecast the morning (09/12/2021).

River levels are rising at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow 09/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen higher than expected at the Izaac Walton, Ilam and Mayfield river gauges as a result of heavier than expected rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout Thursday.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Izaak Walton and Rocester and the Henmore Brook between Carsington Dam and Mayfield. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, however, river levels appear to have peaked and are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech is peaking now at 4.24m; Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.6m Thursday afternoon.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible overnight tonight, Wednesday 8 December 2021.  We expect flooding to affect land and roads.  Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are now falling around Kinnersley Manor, however standing water may still be present. River levels are still rising at Leatherhead and Cobham.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 9 December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Dee due to heavy rainfall. River Levels are forecast to go through the flood alert level in the early hours of tomorrow morning, Thursday 9th December 2021. 
Flooding is possible of low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington in the early hours of tomorrow morning, Thursday 9th December 2021. 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.    
This message will be updated on 9th December 2021, or as the situation changes

Flood warning issued due to strong winds associated with the tail end of Storm Barra expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast this evening, Wednesday 8th December between 19:15-21:15. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. Areas likely to be affected are paths and promenades around Sandside in Scarborough, especially during strong gusts of wind. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous with debris. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. We are monitoring the situation closely. This message will be updated on Thursday morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea at Scarborough - Foreshore Road
items.message: Flood warning issued due to strong winds associated with the tail end of Storm Barra expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast this evening, Wednesday 8th December between 18:15-21:15. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. Areas likely to be affected are paths and promenades around Foreshore road in North bay in Scarborough, especially during strong gusts of wind. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous with debris. You can check flood warnings and alerts on the GOV.UK website or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. We are monitoring the situation closely. items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: Strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast on Wednesday 8th December, between 18:15-21:15. Hazardous conditions might extend 2 hours either side of the high tide. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Scarborough, particularly low lying paths around Scarborough North Bay and Sandside. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Thursday morning, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin after 17:00 today, 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.5m to 6.0m Thursday afternoon, Montford 4.8m to 5.3m overnight Thursday, Welshbridge 2.4m to 2.8m Friday morning, Buildwas 3.6m to 4.0m Friday overnight, Bridgnorth no flooding.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Mersey due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible of low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries throughout today Wednesday 8th December 2021. Further rainfall is forecast this evening and river levels are forecast to peak later this evening, and will remain high throughout the night.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 9th December, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force as river levels remain high following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible overnight into Thursday 09/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, and river levels could remain high until later in the week. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Thursday morning, 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The combination of ongoing spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is 21:45 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, with a level of 5.33 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying coastal roads and farmland is possible this evening, and may occur one to two hours either side of the aforementioned high tide time. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong winds are forecast again for Thursday evening, 09/12/2021, and this flood alert may remain in force for the high tide tomorrow at 22:30. We will keep monitoring the tidal situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, and consider alternative routes. This message will be updated by 16:00 tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: We do not expect to see similar impacts for tonight or tomorrow's high tides and no property flooding is expected from this series of high tides. There is no current flood risk from high tides forecast in this area. Although the risk of flooding has now reduced we will continue to monitor levels closely. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom

items.message: Whilst strong winds are expected at times over the next few days, the tide level is now reducing, and no further impacts are expected.

The Flood Alert for this area has now been removed. 
Coastal conditions should ease for the tides over the coming days. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:15 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 5.09 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morningâ€™s tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:15 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 5.09 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morningâ€™s tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Thursday morning are forecast to be lower than that experienced Wednesday morning. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor ponding in Climping Street Car Park but expect this to reduce over the next few days. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 02:45 Thursday morning 9/12/2021 will be 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.53 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morningâ€™s tide, each subsequent morning tide through to Sunday 12/12/2021 will be lower again. We recycled shingle in November and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Our team have been working to return shingle that had been displaced following Storm Barra. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 13:45 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 4.44 metres Chart Datum (1.70 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. After Thursday morningâ€™s tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.message: We do not expect to see similar impacts for tonight or tomorrow's high tides and no property flooding is expected from this series of tides. There is no current flood risk from high tides forecast in this area. Although the risk of flooding has now reduced we will continue to monitor levels closely. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:00 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 6.23 metres Chart Datum (2.71 mAOD) at Newhaven. After Thursday morningâ€™s tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.message:
The Flood Warning for this area has now been removed. 
Coastal conditions should ease for the tides over the coming days. Please note, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced.
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels all along the River Uck have now returned to near normal, following the heavy rain brought by Storm Barra on Tuesday. The weather forecast suggests Wednesday, Friday and the weekend should remain largely dry in Sussex. However, a band of rain will move across the country Thursday afternoon 9/12/2021. The predicted amount of rain Thursday is currently 7-15mm, which shouldnâ€™t cause significant flooding problems, but river levels will rise again. Possibly to a similar height measured Tuesday, and therefore the risk of minor flooding could return. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again Thursday. You may like to keep flood protection measures in place, or close by. We will re-issue this message if we have increased confidence in the risk of flooding to properties

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Further rainfall is forecast this evening, Thursday 9 December 2021, and we will continue to monitor the situation. Please stay aware in case further flood alerts are issued.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Stapleford river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding is possible along the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   

Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels have risen at Byton river gauge and remain high as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to remain this afternoon, 09/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads to the River Lugg north of Leominster. Locations that may be affected include Yarpole, Mortimers Cross, Kingsland and the B4362.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 20:00 on 09/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  today at 17:00 09/12/21, or as the situation changes

items.message: River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between now and the weekend. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Buxton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is imminent.  Areas most at risk are Litton Mill, and A6 at Buxton.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 09/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents.  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are high and continue to rise on the River Bollin due to heavy rainfall. 
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Bollin, Dean and Pedley, Birkin and Mobberley Brooks and their tributaries this evening, Wednesday 8/12/2021 
Further rainfall is forecast overnight. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated on 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Areas closest to Sankey Brook at Dallam
items.message: River levels are high and continue to rise on the Sankey Brook due to heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected between 01:00 AM and 02:00 AM on Thursday 09/12/2021.  Areas at risk include Chepstow Close, Colwyn Close, properties on and around Higham Avenue, Tavlin Avenue, Hodgkinson Avenue, Marshall Avenue, Hawleys Lane and Mullen Close. Further rainfall is forecast overnight. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Thursday, 9th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye at Wye Bank and Milford at Bakewell
items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Ashford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are Wye Bank, Brook Side, and Milford at Bakewell.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 08:00 today, 09/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.   
Further rainfall is forecast this evening.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 10/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Wingfield Park river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property is possible this morning, 09/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are Ambergate, along the A610, Riversdale Road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until this evening, 09/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and have a bag ready with vital items like medicines and insurance documents.
